Importing Libraries in Python

Sometimes, Pythonâ€™s basic syntax isnâ€™t the most intuitive or doesnâ€™t offer the simplest way to accomplish certain tasks. For example, to calculate a square root in Python, you can raise a number to the power of 0.5.

Thatâ€™s not intuitive. Thatâ€™s why we use libraries.

In Python, libraries (also called modules or packages) contain pre-written code that you can use to simplify your work. Instead of writing everything from scratch, you can import libraries to access functions, classes, and tools for various tasks such as data analysis, web development, and machine learning.

1. Importing a Library

To use a library in Python, you need to import it using the import keyword.

Example: Importing the math Library

Here, we import the math library and use math.sqrt() to calculate the square root of 25.

Notice how we call functions from the imported libraries. We first type the library name (math) followed by a . and the function name (sqrt())

2. Importing with an Alias

You can rename a library using the as keyword to shorten the name for convenience.

Example: Importing NumPy with an Alias

Here, numpy is imported as np, making it easier to call its functions.

Exercise Import pandas library. Use an Alias so that you can run the code below.

3. Importing Specific Functions

Instead of importing the entire library, you can import only the functions you need using from.

Example: Importing Specific Functions

4. Installing and Importing External Libraries

Some libraries are built-in, but others need to be installed first using pip. As you know, we are using a simplified version of Python on this website, so you wonâ€™t be able to run the code below.

Example: Installing Pandas

pip install pandas

If you are using colab to run your code, you need to add ! to your pip statement. pip is a shell (terminal) command - an instruction that you type into a command-line interface (CLI) or terminal to interact with the operating system..

Google Colab is based on Jupyter notebooks an interactive version of Python, where commands executed with ! are interpreted as shell (terminal) commands instead of Python code.

!pip install mysql.connector

5. Commonly Used Libraries in Python

Library Purpose
math Provides mathematical functions like square root, trigonometry, logarithms, and constants (e.g., pi).
random Generates random numbers, shuffles lists, and selects random elements, useful for simulations and games.
datetime Allows working with dates and times, including formatting, comparisons, and time zone handling.
numpy Supports numerical computing with powerful array structures and mathematical functions, essential for data science.
pandas Provides data structures like DataFrames for analyzing, cleaning, and manipulating structured data efficiently.
matplotlib A plotting library used to create graphs, charts, and visualizations for data analysis and reporting.
requests Enables sending HTTP requests to interact with web services and APIs, commonly used for fetching online data.
mysql.connector A MySQL database driver that allows Python to connect, query, and manage MySQL databases efficiently.

Key Takeaways

  • Use import library_name to access built-in libraries.
  • Use import library_name as alias to shorten library names.
  • Use from library_name import function_name to import specific functions.
  • Use pip install library_name to install external libraries before importing.

By mastering imports, you can leverage Pythonâ€™s vast ecosystem of libraries to write powerful and efficient code! ðŸš€
